attributes.description:
Below are a summary of 5 relevant papers and what they implied about this relationship.

Paper number 0
Opinion from: Childhood Maltreatment Was Correlated With the Decreased Cortical Function in Depressed Patients Under Social Stress in a Working Memory Task: A Pilot Study
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyt.2021.671574
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: 
Supporting text used in extraction: We found a significant correlation between cognitive distraction and rumination (p < 0.05).

Paper number 1
Opinion from: Cognitive Impairments in Unipolar Depression: The Impact of Rumination
Paper DOI <link>: 10.1159/000478785
Opinion extracted: inverse
Original user opinion: 
Supporting text used in extraction: These prevailing ruminating thoughts can occupy cognitive resources and lead to a decreased cognitive performance.

Paper number 2
Opinion from: Effect of rejection sensitivity on the development of anxious-depressive attack in Japanese outpatients: The mediating roles of rumination, social anxiety, and depressive symptoms
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyg.2022.1016879
Opinion extracted: Not applicable
Original user opinion: 
Supporting text used in extraction: The intensity of social anxiety correlates with rumination over time in patients undergoing cognitive–behavioral therapy for SAD.

Paper number 3
Opinion from: Cognitive deficits in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome compared to those with major depressive disorder and healthy controls
Paper DOI <link>: 10.1016/j.clineuro.2010.12.002
Opinion extracted: Direct
Original user opinion: 
Supporting text used in extraction: We evaluated the cognitive performance of patients with CFS using standardized verbal and visual memory tests, as well as sustained attention, working memory, and episodic memory. The results showed that patients with CFS had impaired working memory and attention, which could lead to cognitive distraction.

Paper number 4
Opinion from: Improvement in self-reported cognitive functioning but not in rumination following online working memory training in a two-year follow-up study of remitted major depressive disorder
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyt.2023.1163073
Opinion extracted: Uncorrelated
Original user opinion: 
Supporting text used in extraction: Results are mixed regarding whether interventions like computerized working memory training (CWMT) improve rumination, with studies finding support for improvements in some residual symptoms like objective cognitive deficits, but not all, symptoms like subjective cognitive deficits, depressive symptoms, and some aspects of rumination.

Below are a summary of 6 relevant papers and what they implied about this relationship.

Paper number 0
Opinion from: Childhood Maltreatment Was Correlated With the Decreased Cortical Function in Depressed Patients Under Social Stress in a Working Memory Task: A Pilot Study
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyt.2021.671574
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: 
Supporting text used in extraction: We found a significant correlation between forced-failure stress and sadness (p < 0.05).

Paper number 1
Opinion from: Cognitive Impairments in Unipolar Depression: The Impact of Rumination
Paper DOI <link>: 10.1159/000478785
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: 
Supporting text used in extraction: Choking under pressure and working memory capacity: when performance pressure reduces fluid intelligence.

Paper number 2
Opinion from: Effect of rejection sensitivity on the development of anxious-depressive attack in Japanese outpatients: The mediating roles of rumination, social anxiety, and depressive symptoms
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyg.2022.1016879
Opinion extracted: Not applicable
Original user opinion: 
Supporting text used in extraction: The intensity of social anxiety correlates with rumination over time in patients undergoing cognitive–behavioral therapy for SAD.

Paper number 3
Opinion from: Cognitive deficits in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome compared to those with major depressive disorder and healthy controls
Paper DOI <link>: 10.1016/j.clineuro.2010.12.002
Opinion extracted: Not applicable
Original user opinion: 
Supporting text used in extraction: The study did not specifically investigate the relationship between forced-failure stress and sadness. Therefore, there is no direct evidence in the text to support a relationship between these two variables.

Paper number 4
Opinion from: Improvement in self-reported cognitive functioning but not in rumination following online working memory training in a two-year follow-up study of remitted major depressive disorder
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyt.2023.1163073
Opinion extracted: Not applicable
Original user opinion: 
Supporting text used in extraction: No specific mention of forced-failure stress and its relationship to sadness is provided in the text.

Paper number 5
Opinion from: Brain activation patterns in major depressive disorder and work stress-related long-term sick leave 
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3109/10253890.2011.646347
Opinion extracted: Uncorrelated
Original user opinion: 
Supporting text used in extraction: The second pattern (Figure 1, bottom row), which accounted for 29.5% of the cross-block covariance, mainly reflected a difference between the two cognitive tasks (n-back vs. CVMT). During the n-back task, a well-characterized frontoparietal network was activated (Figure 1, bottom row; red), whereas dorsal occipital and temporal polar regions were differentially more engaged during CVMT, and to some degree during the baseline task (Figure 1, bottom row; blue). This effect was similarly expressed across all three groups.

Below are a summary of 3 relevant papers and what they implied about this relationship.

Paper number 0
Opinion from: Cognitive Impairments in Unipolar Depression: The Impact of Rumination
Paper DOI <link>: 10.1159/000478785
Opinion extracted: direct
Original user opinion: 
Supporting text used in extraction: People who ruminate repetitively contemplate reasons for and consequences of their sadness.

Paper number 1
Opinion from: Effect of rejection sensitivity on the development of anxious-depressive attack in Japanese outpatients: The mediating roles of rumination, social anxiety, and depressive symptoms
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyg.2022.1016879
Opinion extracted: Direct
Original user opinion: 
Supporting text used in extraction: Results of a previous study indicated that rumination predicts the onset of depression, exacerbates depression, enhances negative thinking, impairs problem-solving skills, interferes with instrumental behavior, and erodes social support.

Paper number 2
Opinion from: Improvement in self-reported cognitive functioning but not in rumination following online working memory training in a two-year follow-up study of remitted major depressive disorder
Paper DOI <link>: 10.3389/fpsyt.2023.1163073
Opinion extracted: Direct
Original user opinion: 
Supporting text used in extraction: Rumination is an emotion regulation strategy where one passively broods over self-related negative experiences and is hypothesized to be related to deficits in working memory for negative material, sometimes termed hot-cognition. Associations between objective cognitive tests and rumination are small, but significant associations have been established for working memory. Rumination is a central risk factor following remission of mood symptoms and predicts relapse in remitted populations.

This effect was similarly expressed across all three groups.
